Comment 3: 
The home of FHS is: http://www.pathname.com/fhs/

And as you can check all the linux distributions have a policy on (some) compatibility
with FHS:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filesystem_Hierarchy_Standard#Notes_and_references

For Go it means that:

binaries go to: /usr/bin
includes should go to: /usr/include/ or /usr/include/<prefix>[1]
static libraries to: /usr/lib/<prefix>
documentation/source code: /usr/share/<prefix>

Also the /usr/local/{bin,include/<prefix>,lib/<prefix>,share/<prefix>}
should be used for standard installation of non-system packages (but you need to support
multiple tree for that).

Notes:
1. debian packages are using golang as prefix, f.e. /usr/lib/golang
2. I know it's a pain in the ass, but it makes the things easier in the long run.
